loans.use: Purchasing plates and dishes; repairing the roof

loans.name: Radjabi

texts.en:
A. Radjabi is 48 years old. She is married with three children. Radjabi sells fabrics for sewing the national dresses. She has been in this business already for 20 years. Radjabi has very good taste and she is ready to advise her customers which textiles to choose for this or that occasion. That is why she has repeat customers.

Moreover Radjabi’s prices for fabrics are attractive for various levels of the population as she has a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet. All this allows her to keep her clientele and to make a good income. The income that she derives has allowed her to educate her dearest son to a high level. She hopes that she can continue to provide for him, so he will be able to receive an adequate education.

Now Radjabi needs a loan of 800 USD for purchasing new fabrics in order to increase her range of goods. She promises to repay the loan in 12 months without any violation and expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her.

loans.use: Purchasing  new fabrics in order to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is a 40-year-old mother of 5 children who sells dry maize in Kissumu. She is looking for a loan to improve her business by diversifying the products she sells. She would like people to know she is concerned mainly with her family and she wishes people could see how she lives.

loans.use: diversifying the products she sells

loans.name: Ahmadjon

texts.en:
K. Ahmadjon is 43 years old. He is married with 6 children. Ahmadjon manufactures carved wooden doors, window frames, and partitions in the traditional oriental style on order. He has been in this business for 14 years already. Over these years Ahmadjon became a real expert in his business and has a lot of customers.

Since Ahmadjon has a lot of customerss and demand, the business is very successful and brings in stable and significant income, allowing Ahmadjon to improve the living conditions of his family. Now Ahmadjon has a big order for manufacturing window frames and doors. Thus today he requests 550 US Dollars to purchase input materials and wood products for his manufacturing.

The previous loan was managed by Ahmadjon without violations, and he promises to repay the current one on time as well. He is counting on your help and he expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing input materials and wood products for manufacturing window frames and doors

loans.name: Khosiyat

texts.en:
K. Khosiyat is 39 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 4 children. With the purpose to support her family, Khosiyat is selling underwear for women. She has been in this business already for 14 years. Over these years, she gained the experience in choosing goods of good quality that meet the requirements of customers with various levels of income.

The business is very stable which allows Khosiyat to improve the living of the family. Khosiyat has been working with IMON for almost 3 years. She managed her previous loans with accuracy and made all the payments in a timely manner. Today Khosiyat is requesting 1275 US Dollars in order to expand her inventory. Khosiyat would like to thank everyone supporting her and to ensure them that she’ll pay back the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for expanding her inventory

loans.name: Oiniso

texts.en:
K. Oiniso is 45 years old. She and her husband, an engineer, have two children of school age. Oiniso has the specialty of kindergarten teacher. However, for several years already, she has been selling clothing for kids and socks for women and kids.

The income from the business is spent for educating her children, as she and her husband are dreaming that their children will have higher education. Oiniso has been provided with loans by IMON already for 3 years. For the entire period, she has shown herself to be an accurate client. Today she is requesting 675 US for purchasing new goods for sale. Oiniso promises to repay the loan in 9 months and thanks all supporting her.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for sale to broaden her assortment

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en:
N. Rahima is a married woman and has 4 children. She has been running her own business for 5 years already. Rahima sells clothes for kids in a store which is located in one of the intensively inhabited parts of the city. She is very nice and polite and has many customers.

The business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family. Rahima has been a client of IMON for 2 years. She managed to repay all her loans accurately and precisely. Now she requests 550 USD for a period of 12 months. She is planning to purchase clothes for kids for summer season selling. She deeply appreciates your support and sincerely thanks all of you.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for kids for the summer season

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children. She sells clothing at the central market in Melitopol. She has been in this business for 7 years. Large assortment, affordable prices and high client service help Irina to have a successful business. Irina lives with her husband and two sons in a small apartment. She’s got a good family where everybody helps one another.

Irina would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to improve her business conditions. She hopes that patching the holes and giving a new look to her old kiosk would bring even more customers and help her to earn additional income for her family needs.

loans.use: to improve business site conditions

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is a 42-year-old childcare provider. She has no children herself - but loves children. She herself is an orphan and she makes an effort to provide for all of the children in her care equally. She hopes one day to turn enough profit so she can purchase homes to rent to people. When we interviewed her, we talked for about 15 minutes and she is an incredibly warm and vivacious person.

loans.use: buying beds

loans.name: Honoria

texts.en:
Honoria M. owns a small "sari-sari" store. She is 53 years old and has 4 children. Her children are studying and frequently ask her for money to help pay for books and other school projects. Besides running the store, Honoria is a seamstress. She makes good quality dresses that she sells to her regular customers when she is not busy in her store. She cuts and sews fabric to generate additional income for the family.

She is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store. She believes buying more goods will attract more customers. She wants to increase the size of her store to earn a bigger income.

CEVI helps Honoria sustain her business. CEVI provides her with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to help her business grow.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie R. is a 41 year old married mother of two adopted children.  Her husband is a farmer and laborer.  One of her children is in elementary school and the other attends university.  Rosemarie started her 'sari sari' shop - a small store that sells food, beverages, and everyday household items - with money her father gave her when she graduated from college.  She will use the money from this loan to buy more inventory for her shop, which she runs out of her home.  Rosemarie hopes to grow her business and move operations from her house to the public market, where she would like to open a mini-grocery store.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a small general store.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is divorced and has three children. She owns a retail business that sells cosmetics and perfumes at the market in Belaya Tserkov. She started this business when her husband left her.  She has been operating this business for 14 years. Today Svetlana has one employee and many loyal clients. Her main character traits are strength, desire to work, energy and commitment.

Svetlana would like to borrow 5,000 UAH to increase the assortment of inventory. The bulk prices are low at the moment, so Svetlana intends to buy the products when they are cheap and make profitable sales. The additional income will help Svetlana pay for her children's expenses.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of products she sells

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta L. sells a variety of goods in her village. She manages a small sari-sari store and sells rice, sardines, instant noodles, soaps, shampoo, toothpaste, cooking oil and other items.  She is 63 years old and a widow.  Although she is a bit older, she is still strong and able to work. She is also a seamstress. She makes good dresses at the request of her regular customers. She is well known in her village when it comes to dressmaking and repairing clothes.

She is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to sell in her store. The loan will truly help her expand her store and potentially start a new business. 

Modesta has been a CEVI client for a long time. She maintains a good repayment record and pays her principal dues at the cluster meetings every week. CEVI provides her with credit assistance, trainings, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Mrs. Morn Nheb Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The 13 people living in Prasat village in Cambodia's Kandal province who comprise this village bank loan will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. M. N. is a 50-year-old village bank president. She uses hay to make fertilizer that she sells to farmers. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more hay to make more fertilizer to sell and earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Sam Lorn, is a hairdresser. Mrs. M. N. has two children who attend the local school.

Three members of this group have End-of-Term (EoT) loans, while the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. They enable borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a 0% default rate on KiV..

loans.use: Purchasing more hay to make more fertilizer to sell and earn more income.

loans.name: Ustawi Group

texts.en:
Astelia I., age 30, is married with three children ages 13, 9 and 9. She has tailoring business. She started this business ten years ago and works daily from 6am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $187.

This will be Astelia’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She wants to improve her tailoring business and buy more materials to grow her business.

Astelia will share this loan with her loan group, Ustawi, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Astelia is in the front row in the middle in a green dress.

loans.use: Buy more materials

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Trần Thị Hường năm nay 45 tuổi, gia đình chị có 2 con trong đó có 1 con đang tuổi đến trường. Chị Hường tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999. Hiện nay công việc đem alị nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi, kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá và tiền công làm xe ôm của chồng với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị Hường mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua thêm các mặt hàng bia, bánh kẹo... về bán.
texts.en:
Mrs. Trần Thị Hường, 45 years old, has two children, one of whom is still in school. Mrs. Hường has participated in the TYM Fund since 1999. Currently, the main sources of income for her family are raising animals and selling groceries, along with the money her husband earns as a motorbike taxi driver. Their total income each month is about 3,000,000 VND (175 USD). In the next round of lending, Mrs. Hường hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (875 USD) to buy inventory for their grocery shop such as beer, candy, etc.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Twendenawakati Group

texts.en:
Helen M. is 55 years old and a widow with five children ages 34, 30, 25, 20 and 17 years.  She has a chicken business she started in 1994. She works daily from 6am until 7pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $154. 

This will be Helen’s sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy more chickens and pay school fees.  She has repaid the loans successfully and hopes for a sixth loan to buy more chickens and to start selling milk and soda. 
	
Helen will share this loan with her loan group, Twendenawakti, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Helen in the front in blue.

loans.use: Buy more chickens and start to sell milk and soda

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đường năm nay 31 tuổi,  chị đang sống cùng 2 con tại huyện Hưng Nguyên tỉnh Nghệ An. Chồng chị, 33 tuổi, hiện đang  đi lao động  xuất khẩu tại nước ngoài.  Còn chị làm nghề thợ may và chăn nuôi tại nhà. Do thiếu vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và mua vải về cắt may nên năm 2006 chị Đường đã tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương. Đến nay  sau 2 năm tham gia Quỹ với việc  sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả kinh tế gia đình chị đang ngày càng ổn định  hơn với thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng. Với mức vốn 8.000.000đ dự định xin vay trong vòng vốn tới chị sẽ sử dụng để mua trâu và sửa sang chuồng trại phụcvụ cho chăn  nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Đường, 31 years old, lives with her two children in Hưng Nguyên district, Nghệ An province. Her husband, 33 years old, has gone to work overseas. She works at home as a seamstress and raises animals. Because she lacked enough money to buy animals or cloth, in 2006 Mrs. Đường joined the TYM Fund. Now, after two years participating in the Fund and using her loans effectively, the financial situation of her family is steadily becoming more secure, with a monthly income of 5,000,000 VND (297 USD). With the 8,000,000 VND (475 USD) that she has decided to request in the next round of lending, she plans to buy a water buffalo and repair the enclosure she uses to raise animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a water buffalo, repairing animal enclosure

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Hang

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng N. năm nay 59 tuổi,  gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Anh Nhiên chồng chị là cán bộ hưư trí.  Năm 2006 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương để vay thêm vốn về đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi lợn và đây cũng là một trong những nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị bên cạnh  thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 13.000.000đ để mua lợn giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Hằng N., 59 years old, has three grown children. Her husband Nhiên is a retired civil servant. In 2006, she became a member of the TYM Fund and used a loan to invest in raising animals. Currently, in addition to the retirement pension of her husband, the family’s main source of income is raising pigs. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 13,000,000 VND (750 USD) to buy breeding pigs and animal feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Taragire Group

texts.en:
Majaliwa M. is 30 years old and married with a 4 year old daughter. He sells DVDs, CDs, and VCDs and has a video library.  He started his business in 2000 and works daily from 8am until 10pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $154. 

This will be Majaliwa’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase his stock and has repaid the loans successfully. He hopes for a third loan to buy more CDs and DVDs.
	
Majaliwa will share this loan with his loan group, Tarangire, with 6 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Majaliwa, is in the middle in a blue and black shirt.

loans.use: Buy more DVDs and CDs

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel M. is a snack vendor. Everyday, she goes out in the street to sell various food items like chippy, bananacue, ice candy and other delicacies to earn an income for her family. She is 30 years old and has 2 children. She previously worked in Mitzumi, an electronic company in the Philippines. She became pregnant while she was working and decided to go back to her province to get married. In 2000, she started her business. Her snack business is growing and becoming better. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to construct a snack house. She will use part of the loan for additional capital in her business. This loan will truly help Rachel increase her profits and help her provide for her family.

CEVI provides her credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage and provides her a better chance to succeed and make her business grow.

loans.use: To construct a snack house and for additional capital for her business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth M. is a Tanzanian micro entrepreneur. She runs a business selling water to customers for domestic uses. She owns a well at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. Water is very important and a scarce commodity in many developing countries due to environmental degradation. She plans to drill another well to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to drill a water well.

loans.use: To drill a new well

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie L. is 53 years old, married and a mother of four. Elsie manufactures, buys and sells pottery. She delivers the finished products to her customers. 

The  business started when she attended a  livelihood training in pot making seminar. She will use her current loan amounting to P 9,000.00 in purchasing pot making materials.

She aspires to have a stall in the market as a source of income and to send her children to school.

loans.use: purchasing of pots and pottery making materials

loans.name: Kasanda

texts.en: Kasanda M. is a Tanzanian small businessman. He is married with two children. He runs a modern barber shop at Kisiwan Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam. He also sells phone accessories there. He purchases phone accessories wholesale from Kariakoo and sells them to his customers. He would like a loan of  600,000 TZS to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi: Chị Ngô Thị Bình  năm nay 37 tuổi,  chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999 và đang kinh doanh hàng ăn . Anh Tâm  chồng chị là thợ cơ khí với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài thời gian đi làm anh cũng giúp đỡ chị rất nhiều vì thế công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị  phát triển tốt và cho thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thực phẩm phục vụ cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ngô Thị Bình, 37 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 1999 and currently runs a restaurant. Her husband Tâm works as a mechanic and earns 2,000,000 VND (115 USD) per month. When he is not working at his regular job, he helps Mrs. Bình a great deal in the restaurant, and because of this the business is doing very well and earns the family 2,500,000 VND (144 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 20,000,000 VND (1150 USD) to invest in buying raw ingredients to use in the family’s restaurant.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restaurant

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en: Lourdes G. is a 46-year-old widowed mother of seven.  Two of her children are still in primary school, and three attend high school.  She applied for this loan to raise the capital to start a hog raising business.  Lourdes plans to install a pen to hold the pigs in her backyard, and will buy three piglets to start.  In the past, Lourdes has been a food vendor but she hopes this new business will provide her with greater income as she needs money to pay for her children's education.  She dreams of having all her children finish high school and wants them to attend college if possible.

loans.use: To buy three piglets, six sacks of feed, and vitamins for the pigs.

loans.name: Oumar

texts.fr: Agé de 41 ans oumar est un marchand de friperie .chaque matin il va au marche pour s'approvisionner en quelques pantalons chemises et autres objets de friperie qu'il va vendre à travers les rues et ruelles de la ville.Les revenus tirés de la vente de ces objets lui permet d 'entretnir sa famille.Avec le pret qu'il sollicite oumar veut renforcer les quantites de marchandises qu'il achette pour reduire des couts d' approvisionnement et accroitre se revenus.
texts.en:
Oumar, age 41, is a second-hand clothing reseller. Every morning, he goes to the market to get his supplies : a few trousers, shirts, and other used clothing items, that he then sells in the streets of the city. The profits of his business enables him to provide for his family. With the loan he's seeking, Oumar would like to increase the amount of items he buys, in order to reduce the supply cost and increase his profits.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for his second-hand clothing business

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali, Rwanda!  Antoinette M. is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company.  She has owned a small shop in the Gasabo district of the capital city for ten years.  Each day she works from 7:00 am to 9:00 pm which allows her to earn a profit of approximately 100,000 Rwandan Francs each month ($200 USD).  She has two employees who help her run the shop.  

Antoinette is requesting a loan of 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be paid back over a period of eight months.  She will use the loan to buy a refrigerator for her shop so that she can sell cold drinks.  

Antoinette is 58 years old, widowed, and has three children.  In addition, she cares for four dependants.  She hopes that this loan will help her increase her monthly profit so it will be easier for her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase a new refrigerator

loans.name: Lam Thi

texts.vi: Chị Soa  năm nay 48  tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con huyện Hưng Nguyên Tỉnh Nghệ An. Hai con của chị đều đang tuổi đến trường còn chồng chị là thương binh, anh làm nghề sửa xe. Chị Soa hiện làm công việc thu  gom rác tại địa phương . Bên cạnh đó gia đình chị còn chăn nuôi lợn gà để tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.  Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị là 4.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 12.000.000đ để đầu tư mua nguyên vật liệu sửa chữa nhà và chuồng trại phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Soa, 48 years old, is living with her husband and two children in Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. The two children are at school age, and her husband - a disabled veteran - works as a bike repairer. Mrs. Soa currently works as garbage collector in the area. In addition, her family also raises pigs and chickens to increase the family's income. The family's income currently is VND4,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND12,000,000 to buy materials to renovate the house and the barn for livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Renovate house and barn for livestock

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: FATOU est une femme mariée  elle est agée de 34 ans .elle vit dans la concession de son mari .son principale activité est le commerce de tissus qu 'elle vend aux femmes de quartier.Elle fait ce metier depuis plusieurs années.Les revenus tirés de cette activité lui permettent de satisfaire des depenses mineures des enfants.avec le prt qu élle compte renforcer son fond de commerce pour profiter de l"arriver des vendeurs saisions de tissus pour augmenter ses stocks.
texts.en:
Fatou is 34 years old, married, and lives at her husband's house. For several years, her main business has been consisting in selling fabrics to women in her neighborhood. The profits of this business enables her to provide for the children's small expenses. With this loan, she intends to bolster her stock by taking advantage of the arrival of the seasonal cloth vendors.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma M. is a 64-year-old mother of 10 whose husband is a farmer.  One of her children is still in college, and eight are university graduates.  Norma plans to use this loan to buy inventory such as soft drinks, beer, liquor, and cigarettes for her 'sari sari' store.  'Sari sari' stores are small variety shops found across the Philippines, usually operated out of the proprietor's house.  Besides the shop, Norma also makes money by selling vegetables from time to time.  Norma hopes that one day she will be able to expand her store.

loans.use: To buy inventory such as soft drinks and cigarettes for a small general store.

loans.name: Farad

texts.en: Farad is the son of R. and lives in the 16th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single, but is the oldest of the family. He needs to cover all the necessities of his family and pay for all their expenses. He runs a car part shop for which he still needs some tools. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the term of 12 months and would like to make his business vast. He is confident that the loan will help him to increase his business.

loans.use: For buying more materials

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị Phú  năm nay 43 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 1998. Chồng chị  anh Phan Văn Ngân làm nghề thợ xây cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng .Hiện tại chị đang chăn nuôi, trồng trọt  tại nhà cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Với mức thu nhập ổn định này gia đình chị đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm trâu, vịt về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi P., 43 years old, has participated in TYM Fund since 1998. Her husband, Mr. Phan Van Ngan, works as a construction worker with a wage of VND2,000,000 per month. Currently she farms and raises livestock at home with an income of VND2,000,000 per month. With this stable income, her family has financial resources to improve the living condition.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND10,000,000 to buy additional buffaloes and ducks to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy additional buffaloes and ducks to raise.

loans.name: Agathe

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali, Rwanda! Agathe M. is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company.  She has owned a shop selling clothes, shoes, and bags in the Nyarugenge neighborhood of the capital city for two years.  She works daily from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm and earns approximately 400,000 Rwandan Francs per month before expenses ($800 USD).  She is requesting a loan of 500,000 Rwandan Francs to be paid back over a period of eight months to increase her stock at her shop.  Specifically, she intends to purchase more shoes and bags because they are popular items.  

Agathe is 35 years old, married, and has four children.  Her children are two, three, five and eleven years old.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of shoes and bags

loans.name: Jolita

texts.en:
Jolita A. is a rice grower. She and her husband till their land to support the needs of their five children. She is now 52 years old. She has been a farmer ever since she was just a small kid. Her parents taught her everything she needed to know to plant and harvest rice. Aside from rice, she also grows vegetables in their backyard. She waters them everyday. Her harvest is what she uses to buy the other things they need. 

She is asking CEVI for a loan of Php 8,000. She will use the loan to buy four sacks of Urea fertilizer as well as herbicides. Her loan will definitely help her achieve a better yield. 

CEVI provides their client with the credit assistance that they need. Aside from that, they give all their clients training and insurance coverage

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and herbicide

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita M. is a 69-year-old widowed mother of five. Her children have all moved out, and since her husband has died, she lives alone. Juanita has a business selling herbal medicine. Most of the customers she serves live in her barangay (Filipino for district or village), while some are in neighboring barangays.

Juanita plans to use this loan to buy more inventory for her business. In the future she hopes to expand her sales territory. She also would like to secure another means of transportation when on her sales route as when she travels now, she pays for rides on the back of a truck.

loans.use: To buy herbal medicines for resale

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị  Nguyễn Thị Nguyệt  năm nay 31 tuổi,  chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007 và đang  làm nghề kinh doanh sơn và nhôm kính. Anh Tuấn  chồng chị là thợ nhôm kính có tay nghề cao nên cũng hỗ trợ chị rất nhiều trong công việc kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đang phát triển rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 4.500.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm các loại sơn và nguyên liệu phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất , kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. is 31 years old. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2007, and currently she sells paints, glasses and aluminum frames. Mr Tuan, her husband, is a skilled worker in glass and aluminum frames so he can help her a lot in the business. The business of her family is going well and brings an income of VND4,500,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND20,000,000 to buy additional paints and materials for her family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy additional paints and materials for her family's business.

loans.name: Delfa

texts.en:
She is 44 year old, married and blessed with four children. 

Delfa has a variety store. She started this business with the profit she got from hog fattening. At first, she decided to build the store beside her piggery so that she could monitor both businesses. Her current loan will be for additional capital for the store and for the expansion plan.

Delfa’s dream is to have a convenience store someday. She also wants her children to finish college and find a good job for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase can goods, noodles etc. for her store

loans.name: Solange's Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Solange N. who lives in the Nyarugenge district of the capital city Kigali, Rwanda! Nine years ago, Solange started a business selling men's and women's clothing.  She employs one person to help her run the shop and earns approximately 116,000 Rwandan Francs in profit each month ($230 USD).   Solange is requesting a loan worth 500,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company, S.A. to expand her business. Specifically, she hopes to increase her inventory by buying clothing in bulk to sell to her clients.  She will repay this loan over eight months on a monthly basis.

Solange is 26 years old and married with three children.

loans.use: To buy more clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Yao

texts.en: Yao K. lives in Thkouv village in Cambodia's Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Puth Teng, pictured on the left, is a construction worker. Since his workplace is far from the house, he spends a lot of money on motor taxis. Yao K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work. She hopes this loan will enable her to reduce expenses and provide a better life for her family. She is 61 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other attends the local school.

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Chrun

texts.en: Chrun P. lives in Pech Sar village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She earns a living as a farmer, cultivating rice on a plot of land that she owns. She faces problems with this cultivation because her field is infertile and she does not have much money to buy rice seeds and pesticides. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, rice seeds and insecticide to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Morn Pork, is a construction worker. Chrun P. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a laborer who has been hired to thresh rice. Two of her children attend the local school, while the youngest is too young to work or study. She and her husband are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizer, rice seeds and insecticide to make her crops more productive.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị  Nguyễn Thị L. năm nay 38 tuổi,  chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007 Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị đều kinh doanh vật liệu xây dựng và đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị với mức thu nhập hàng tháng là 4.000.000đ   Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., 38 years old, has participated in TYM Fund since 2007. Currently, both she and her husband sell construction materials. This is the business that brings the main source of income for her family, at VND4,000,000 per month.

In this L. cycle, she wishes to borrow VND20,000,000 to invest more in her family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for construction materials business

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en: Mrs. Khorn Y. is a villager in Trapaing Knol village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Chor Phal, is a construction worker. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Khorn Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income to support her family. She is 57 years old and the mother of six children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Saren

texts.en: Mrs. Saren C. lives in Trapaing Knol village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is doing well, she wants to expand it by buying more ducks to add to her breeding stock to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Nim Vuthy, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. He also sells firewood. Mrs. Saren C. is 22 years old and the mother of three children who are too young to work or study. She and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: Buying more ducks to add to her breeding stock to earn more income.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Greetings from Rachel U. in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda!  Rachel owns a small garage where she provides maintenance for vehicles.  She is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company S.A. for 500,000 RWF so that she can buy more stock in order to have all parts and tools necessary for making repairs.  She will repay the loan over a period of eight months on a monthly basis.  Rachel works every day from 7:00 am to 9:00 pm and earns approximately 450,000 Rwandan Francs ($820 USD) in sales each month.   She has owned the business for seven years and employs three people.  

Rachel is 26 years old, married, and has three children.

loans.use: To purchase more tools and vehicle parts

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en: Dulmaa S. is a widowed mother of three children. She lives with her eldest son in Uvurhangay, one of Mongolia's southern provinces. Her two youngest sons are college students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. Together with her eldest son, Tumurbaatar, she runs a raw hide business that uses yak, sheep and goat skins. Her son buys raw hides from countryside herders and she then sells them to buyers in the center of the province. Sometimes Tumurbaatar goes to Ulaanbaatar to sell raw hides for a higher price. Dulmaa also runs a sewing business from her home, making traditional coats called "deels." During April, students who will graduate in May order traditional dresses for their graduation celebration. To prepare for the spike in demand Dulmaa prepares many different colors of silk. Dulmaa has a wonderful work ethic and a positive attitude. She will use the loan she receives to invest in her business by increasing her inventory of silk and raw hides.

loans.use: To buy silk and raw hides

loans.name: Lat

texts.en: Mrs. Lat K. lives in An Doung Samrith village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She also sells palm sugar which is made by her husband. Her husband, Mr. Thun Tha, is a palm juice collector. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn too little income to provide a better house for their family living. Thus, Mrs. Lat K. decided to request a loan to buy zinc and timbers. She would use the rest of the loan to hire a laborer to build the house. She is 45 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom work in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. She and her husband are presented in the picture.

loans.use: To buy zinc and timbers,  and  hire a laborer to build a house.

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en: Mrs. Lonh I. lives in Pech Sar village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder. Her husband, Mr. Kong Kosal, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from ownI. this plantation, he makes baskets to sell to earn income. Now Mrs. Lonh I. is requestI. a loan to buy more ducks to grow her poultry business, and she would use the rest of the money to purchase rice seed and fertilizer for production in the field. She is 43 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attendI. the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to grow her poultry business and to purchase rice seed and fertilizer for production in the field

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en: Altantsetseg D. is 41 years old, married, and has two sons. She runs a sewing business out of a 10 square meter rental room. In 2007, she started her business by buying a sewing machine and fabric that cost MNT 40,000 ($1.00 USD=1,600.00 MNT). Her business has been successful ever since and allowed her to purchase three more sewing machines and hire two tailors. Her working capital has grown from 40,000 MNT to 1.5 million MNT. Her daily income now is around 1.0 million MNT. She gets many orders due to the lack of competing businesses in her area. With her profits, her husband built a 40 sq. meter house on the plot of land that they own. Before her business flourished, she lived in a "ger" (traditional, nomadic form of tent housing) in the local ger district. One of her sons goes to elementary school, the other one is a university student. Her husband operates a taxi business that brings in MNT 250,000-300,000 every month. Altantsetseg requests a loan to purchase more silk for her business since spring is coming and college graduation approaches. At graduation, students wear traditional clothing made with silk. Altantsetseg dreams of hiring two more tailors and expanding her workplace further.

loans.use: to buy silk

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Mrs. Sean K. was born in 1959 and now lives in An Doung Samrith village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Heng Lo, is a teacher in the local school. This couple has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a cow breeder and the remaining is a farmer who helps with the plantation. Mrs. Sean K. is applying for a loan to buy a cart to use with an electric motor for transportation. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cart to use with an electric motor for transportation

loans.name: Lhamdegd

texts.en:
Lhamdegd B. is a married mother of two. She runs a dairy food stall with her eldest daughter. Her youngest daughter is a university student in UlaanB., the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is retired and stays at home. The family lives in a little house that is built on a plot of land they own.

She buys dairy products such as cow's milk and different types of aaruul (dried milk) from herders and sells them in her food stall at the local market of Uvurhangay province. Uvurhangay is a one of Mongolia's southern provinces.

With this loan, Lhamdegd will buy more dairy food to expand her business' inventory. She says in Mongolian, "I'm aiming to collect as much money as I can from my business profit for my youngest daughter's tuition. I want my daughter to become a professional person and wish her a happy and rich life."

loans.use: To buy dairy products

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Soeurn U. is a farmer in Trapaing Knol village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Am Ann, owns a small business that sells sugar and firewood. In his business, he has a difficult time because he does not have a motorbike to transport his goods. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Soeurn U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband’s business. She is 30 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband’s business

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda! Emmanuel is currently requesting his first loan from Kiva partner Vision Finance Company, S.A. worth 500,000 Rwandan Francs.  He owns a business in which he rents out wiring and sound materials such as microphones, mixers, and speakers. His business is located in Muhima sector, Nyarugenge District, Kigali city.

He has owned this business for eight years and employs one person. He works every day from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. and earns a profit of approximately 180,000 Rwandan Francs each month (about $350). He will use the loan to buy more sound equipment to use in his business in order to satisfy his customers' needs. 

Emmanuel is 27 years old and married.

loans.use: To buy more sound equipment for his rental business

loans.name: Ulziyjargal

texts.en:
Ulziyjargal P. is a married mother of three. For the last three years, together with her husband, she has run a family-owned carpentry business. In 2006, the couple bought woodworking tools and began to make furniture to sell. Both husband and wife are professional carpenters. Ulziyjargal's eldest daughter stays at home to take care of her youngest sister and their one son is a Buddhist monk at a local temple. Ulziyjargal's family lives in Uvurhangay province, which is located 400km southwest of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Ulziyjargal usually makes the deals for raw materials while her husband builds tables and other furniture. With this loan, Ulziyjargal will buy more wood and paint. The couple dreams of expanding into a furniture factory. Ulziyjargal says in Mongolian, "I want my children to keep our family business and continue expanding it as big as a furniture factory."

(In the picture: Ulziyjargal's husband making a table)

loans.use: To buy wood and paint

loans.name: Tumur

texts.en:
Tumur L. lives with her husband in Uvurhangay, one of Mongolia's southern provinces. She has one son who has been working in South Korea the last few years.

Since 1998, Tumur has been running a butcher shop at the local food market. She mainly sells mutton from a rented stall. On average she sells eight sheep per day. Her husband helps her business by buying animals from herders and dressing the carcasses to get ready for sale. She adds MNT 600.0 per kg ($1 = MNT 1600) to the wholesale price.

Normally in the countryside, meat prices increase in the summer and decrease during the winter. Tumur has a small storage unit to freeze meat, which she uses to store sheep bought when the price is cheaper than in summer. Her loan will be used to purchase more sheep.

Together with her husband, she plans to one day own the shop she operates from.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en:
Dioscora P. B. is a "sari-sari" or variety store owner. Ten years ago, she started her store using her small savings of PHP 3,000. Because of her strong entrepreneurial spirit, she was able to sustain her business and make it grow. Aside from her sari-sari store, she also owns a multicab. She earns a reasonable profit from her multicab which she uses to feed and clothe her family. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP 21,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional stock for her store. She will also use some of the loan to buy parts and accessories for her multicab.

CEVI provides all their clients the credit assistance, trainings and insurance coverage. They help their clients start and grow their small businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Emerenciana

texts.en:
Emerenciana T. owns a small "sari-sari" store. It is situated 100 meters away from her house. People come to her store to buy their staples. She sells rice, sardines, instant coffee, noodles, beverages, soaps, shampoos, bread, chippy, and other goods. Her profit goes to pay her children's tuition fees. Because of her store, she was also able to pay for books and other school supplies. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP 21,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to attract customers. The loan will truly help Emerenciana expand her business. In this way, she believes, she will have more to contribute to the family income. 

CEVI provides their clients credit assistance that they need. They also give their clients training and insurance coverage to help their clients grow their businesses.

loans.use: To expand her store's inventory

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela B. makes hats for a living. She is 59 years old and has 3 children. She previously worked as a waitress in a restaurant in her town. When her husband proposed marriage, she stopped working and went back to their barrio. Her business is making native hats and mats. She earns enough income to pay for her children's education. Aside from weaving native hats, she has a small garden in her backyard. She and her children water it every day. She uses the profit from her harvest to pay for their other needs.

She is requesting a loan of PHP 18,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional materials for her beautiful hats. She is also interested in establishing a small sari-sari store. Her loan will definitely help her expand her business and get started in a new business.

CEVI supports Rosela in her business. She is provided with the same credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage CEVI gives to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making hats

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr:
D. Georgette est originaire de DJIGBE un petit village du département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Mais, elle est Née le 06 Janvier 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit présentement dans la maison de sa mère au quartier Kpondehou. Georgette est célibataire sans enfant et coiffeuse de profession. Cependant Georgette ne fait pas la coiffure par manque de moyens financières pour ouvrir un salon de coiffure. Georgette exerce l'activité de la vente de glacières,bassines, bols, plats en plastique ainsi que des produits de cheveux et de beauté. Georgette va s'approvisionner à TOKPA, marché international du BENIN. Ensuite, Georgette distribue ses produits à crédit à ses clientes dans les quartiers environnant. Georgette repasse après quelques jours collecter son argent auprès de ces clientes selon le délais fixé à chacune. Sa clientèle augmente ainsi que leur demande; c'est pourquoi Georgette sollicite de crédit afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.  


 
La signification d’ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique d’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux a 0% d’intérêt aux gens très vulnérables et il est dans un groupe qui lancent bientôt un programme de la microassurance santé.
texts.en:
Georgette D.'s family comes from Djigbe, a small village in the Ouémé department in Bénin. She was born in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, where she currently lives at her mother's house in the Kpondehou neighborhood. Georgette is unmarried and doesn't have children. She's a trained hairdresser, but is not practicing at this time because she lacks the financial means to open a hairdressing salon. Instead, she sells coolers, basins, bowls, plastic ware, as well as cosmetics and hair care products. Georgette gets her supplies at the Topka market, an international marketplace in Bénin. She then resells her products on credit in the surrounding neighborhoods. After a few days, she comes back to collect the money from her customers, according to the specified payment terms. Her clientele is growing, which is the reason why Georgette is seeking a loan in order to meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an resell coolers, basins, bowls, plastic ware, cosmetics and hair care products

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Agée de 39 ans, Mme Afi G. est mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants tous scolarisables. Elle n’a jamais mis pied à l’école, c’est pourquoi elle s’efforce pour instruire ses enfants dont la charge de scolarité pèse sur elle seule. Elle tire ses maigres revenus à travers la vente de noix de palme, lesquels revenus n’arrivent pas à couvrir les charges du ménage et la les frais de scolarité des enfants. Pour renforcer son petit commerce et augmenter ses revenus, elle sollicite un crédit. C’est une femme très dynamique qui mérite d’être encouragée.
texts.en:
Mrs. Afi G., age 39, is married and the mother of three school-attending children. She never went to school, which is the reason why she tries very hard to get an education for her children, whose school expenses she supports on her own. She gets her meager income from selling palm nuts, but said income is not sufficient to cover both the household and the school expenses. To bolster her small business and increase her income, she's seeking a loan. Being a very energetic woman, she deserves to be encouraged.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell palm nuts

loans.name: Todjiniso

texts.en:
Todjiniso S.’s passion lies with children. A married mother of three, Todjiniso opened her business selling women’s clothing with the goal of providing a better standard of living for her family. For the past three years, Todjiniso has successfully operated her business at the market. With her profits, she not only has improved her children's living standards, she has been able to support her elderly parents as well.

Todjiniso has requested a loan of $675 to restock her clothing inventory. An optimistic businesswoman, Todjiniso plans to use the loan to continue developing her business and supporting her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new women's clothing for the spring season to resell.

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
Ulugbek S. is a young boy who likes to make his own way. He runs a clothing business, which is how Ulugbek supports his family, including his parents and brother. Little by little and with hard work his business has expanded. Still, Ulugbek wants his business to grow even more.

For this reason he is requesting a loan of $675, which he will pay back in 12 months. With the money, Ulugbek will buy more merchandise. This way he will have new products to offer to his customers. With your help, Ulugbek will be able to establish himself, save money, expand his business, and form a family.

loans.use: Tp purchase new clothing for resale.

loans.name: Ganyo

texts.fr:
Marié et père de quatre (04) enfants, Mr Ganyo K. est un cultivateur de 31 ans. Malgré sa volonté, sa capacité et sa force de travail, il n’a que de faibles rendements à la fin de chaque campagne agricole à cause de l’infertilité de sa surface cultivable. 
A cet effet, il sollicite un financement pour s’acheter de l’engrais afin d’améliorer sa productivité les saisons à venir. Ce financement lui donnera l’opportunité de jouir de ses potentialités et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Ganyo K. is 31 years old, married, and the father of 4 children. He's a farmer who, in spite of his will, capability and work strength, only gets low crop yields due to the infertility of the area he cultivates. He is therefore seeking a loan to purchase fertilizers, in order to increase his production for the coming seasons. This loan will give him the opportunity to enjoy his potential and to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Makhsud

texts.en:
The need to improve his income and provide education for his 4 dear children are the reasons Makhsud is courteously requesting this loan. He is a very responsible and hard-working father who for many years has been dedicated to the business of buying and selling shoes.

Makhsud has so far accessed loans from IMON International five times and has seen his business expand. With the income, he said he was able to educate his children as that is the most important for Maksud. Today he is requesting a loan of 850 USD to expand the business so that he can generate more income in order to be able to arrange the wedding of his son. Maksud is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve his dreams with this loan.

loans.use: Purchasing new shoes for his inventory

loans.name: Mehrovar

texts.en:
Mehrovar is a very ambitious young man with amazing selling skills. He is 20 years old, lives in Dushanbe, and has been working in the clothing industry for the past 3 years. He was able to expand his small business, over the year, into a well-known shop in the neighborhood.

Mehrovar is a very enterprising lad with a great desire to get ahead. His business has been able to show the fruits of his labor and he hopes to grow as a businessman. He needs a loan of 675 USD, which he plans to invest in inventory in order to offer better service and variety to his customers. You can be an important part of the growth of this business.

loans.use: Purchasing  new clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Cyrielle

texts.fr:
Née le 18 Mars 1985 à Cotonou la capitale économique du BENIN, G. Cyrielle est originaire de Porto-Novo la capitale politique du Bénin. Mère d'une fille de 4 ans scolarisée, Cyrielle a divorcé de son mari depuis 2 ans et a, à sa charge son unique fille. Cyrielle vit actuellement dans la maison de son père au quartier Dédokpo, un quartier populaire de la ville de Cotonou qui fait corps avec le lac Nokoué. Cyrielle dispose d'une cabine téléphonique avec deux combinés téléphoniques. Cyrielle vend les cartes de recharges de tous les réseaux téléphoniques mobiles au Bénin. Cyrielle a encore ouvert une cafétariat. Cyrielle envisage faire aussi la pâtisserie. Car au niveau de sa caféteriat, la demande de ses clientes en  pâtisserie est forte. C'est dans cette optique que Cyrielle sollicite de crédit pour étendre ses activités. 
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l'Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born on March 18, 1985 in Cotonou, the economic capital of BENIN, Ms. G. Cyrielle has roots in Porto-Novo, the political capital of Bénin. She is a mother with one 4-year-old daughter, who is in school. Cyrielle divorced her husband two years ago and supports her only child. Cyrielle currently lives in her father’s house in Dédokpo, a working-class district of the city of Cotonou that is squarely located on Lake Nokoué. She runs a telephone booth having two handsets. She sells recharge phone cards of all the mobile phone networks in Bénin. In addition, she has opened a cafeteria, where customer demand for pastries is strong. Because of this outlook, Cyrielle is requesting a loan to expand her businesses. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for micro-loan recipients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric oven for pastries, some phone cards, and cans of evaporated milk

loans.name: Radjabali

texts.en:
Radjabali is a 33-year-old, married father of 5 children. He provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store he owns. He is requesting a loan of $700 for the term of 9 months to increase the stock of food goods available at his store. Radjabali is ready to work even harder and make sacrifices to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur and supporting his children's efforts to get good educations. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will ensure the success of his small business.

loans.use: Purchase foodstuffs to increase range of goods for sale in his grocery store

loans.name: Amriddin

texts.en:
Amriddin is married and has 5 children. Due to the lack of jobs in his town, Dushanbe, Tajikistan, to provide for his family Amriddin started his own business selling sewing machines and supplies (needle, thread, and other small items) about 14 years ago. He has become well-known in his town, and his sales have increased. To continue growing his business, Amriddin is requesting a loan in the amount of $1300 to purchase more merchandise to offer customers greater variety and quality of products and to provide better customer service. He commits to repaying this loan within 12 months. Be part of this business and support Amriddin. He and his family thank you very much!

loans.use: To purchase sewing machine and supplies for it.

loans.name: Zainiddin

texts.en:
Zainiddin is 39 years old. Together with his wife they are raising their three children. Zainiddin is working hard to get a better lifestyle and rise out of poverty. He has a workshop where he repairs electronic products such as TVs, tape recorders, radios, and the like. Today Zainiddin requests $600 to purchase spare parts and supplies to increase his income and be able to send his elder son to university. He promises to repay the loan within 9 months. Your support will really help him; be an important part of the growth of Zainiddin’s business.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts to grow his electronics repair business.

loans.name: Assiba

texts.fr:
Originaire de Ketou un petit village du département de Sèmè Podji situé à 10 Km de la ville de Porto-Novo la capitale politique du BENIN. D. Assiba est agée de 65 ans. Mariée à ATALE Léonel un peintre bâtiment de profession, Assiba est mère de 6 enfants tous majeurs. Assiba vit à Cotonou au quartier AGBODJEDO où elle vendait il y a 10 ans du poisson fumé. Mais depuis 5 ans maintenant Assiba a laissé cette activité au profit de la vente du  haricot en détail et du sodabi, une boisson locale alcoolisée et très appréciée du peuple béninois. Ses clients potentiels sont les restaurateurs à qui Assiba livre surtout cette boisson. Assiba va régulièrement s'approvisionner dans les villages à l'interieur du Bénin. Aujourd'hui Assiba a deux de ses petits fils à sa charge et elle dépense en moyenne 1500 F par jour pour nourrir sa famille. La demande de ses produits est très forte sur le marché. C'est pourquoi D. Assiba demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer ses activités. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour ses clients. 
 

i
texts.en:
Having roots in Ketou, a small village in Sèmè Podji County (located 10 km from the city of Porto-Novo, the political capital of BENIN), Ms. D. Assiba, age 65, is married to Mr. ATALE Léonel, a house painter by profession. Assiba is the mother of six children, all of age. She lives in Cotonou in the AGBODJEDO district, where she used to sell smoked fish ten years ago. But five years ago, she dropped that business in favor of retail sales in beans and sodabi, a local alcoholic drink that is highly appreciated by the people of Benin. Her potential customers are restauranteurs to whom Assiba makes deliveries, especially this drink. She regularly goes to get supplies from inland villages of Benin. Today, she supports two of her grand-daughters and spends 1,500 francs on average each day to feed her family. The market demand for her merchandise is very strong. That’s why she’s requesting a third loan, so as to bolster her business. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for its clients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of beans and a 50-liter drum of sodabi

loans.name: Ziyadulla

texts.en:
T. Ziyadulla is 47 years old. He is a farmer who works on his land growing vegetables. He is assisted by his wife and elder sons. For the current planting season, he wants to plant high-quality potatoes, cucumbers and tomatoes so he can improve the quality of his harvest. With the loan money, Ziyadulla will be able to finance his current farming season to get a better harvest, enabling him to repay on schedule. The loan will greatly improve Ziyadulla’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
D. Shuhrat is married and the father of 2 children. An electrician by training, he left this trade in favor of truck farming,  a very profitable business that requires significant financial means. Today he needs to expand his cultivatable land and increase his revenues. Shuhrat seeks a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. This will allow him to increase his production and better satisfy his clientele.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Christiane

texts.fr:
Originaire de GLO, un petie village du département de l'Atlantique situé à près de 100 Km de la ville de Cotonou la capitale économique du BENIN. A. Christiane est âgée de 45 ans. Veuve depuis 8 ans, A. Christiane est mère de cinq enfants dont 2 garçons et 3 filles. Seuls les trois derniers enfants sont scolarisés. Il s'agit de Damien âgé de 11 ans en classe de CM1, de Gisèle âgée de 9 ans en classe de CE2 et le benjamin âgé de 8 ans et en classe de CE1. En plus de ses enfants A. Christiane a, à sa charge une de ses sœurs qui l'aide dans la vente du maïs.A. Christiane dépense en moyenne 1000 F pour les dépenses alimentaires de sa famille. La famille vit à GANKPODO un quartier périphérique de la ville de Cotonou depuis 25 ans où A. Christiane exerce l'activité de la vente du pain de façon ambulante et du maïs en détail chez elle à la maison. A. Christiane envisage diversifier son activité par la vente des divers (cartons de sucre, de biscuits, de lait concentré et en poudre, des détergents, des bombons, de la farine de manioc, etc.) A. Christiane veut aussi renforcer la vente du maïs en s'approvisionnant en grande quantité  de maîs. Car par moment A. Christiane se retrouve en rupture de stock alors que la demande existe. C'est pour ces différentes raisons que A. Christiane sollicite son premier crédit. 


p> 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Having roots in GLO, a small village in Atlantique County (located 10 km from the city of Porto-Novo, the political capital of BENIN), Ms. A. Christiane, age 45, has been a widow for eight years and is the mother of five children (two boys and three girls). Only the last three are in school: Damien, age 11, in the 4th grade; Gisèle, age 9, in the 3rd grade; and the youngest son, age 8, is in the 2nd grade. In addition to her children, she supports one of her sisters who helps with selling corn.

A. Christiane spends 1,000 francs on average for food for her family. She and her family have been living in GANKPODO, an outlying district of the city of Cotonou, for 25 years. There, she works selling bread door-to-door and corn at the retail level out of her home.

She envisions diversifying her business by selling various goods (boxes of sugar, cookies, evaporated and powdered milk, detergents, candy, cassava flour, etc.) She also wants to boost her sales of corn, since she is out of stock at the moment, while the demand is still there. For these different reasons, she’s requesting her first loan.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for receipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 100-kg sacks of corn and various goods for resale

loans.name: Kuziboy

texts.en:
M. Kuziboy has been in the farming business for 22 years. It is through farming that he was able to provide for his family and send his children to school, even though they were not able to earn a college degree. Kuziboy would like to request a loan of 4500 Somoni to buy necessary farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers, as they are very expensive. He is very optimistic that this will improve his yield and he hopes to have a continuous partnership with the lenders. Kuziboy always makes sure that he respects the people around him because he believes that respect begets respect.  

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of Alexander the Great's rule.  It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes,  is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and to a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Ân năm nay 48  tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tìnhthương từ năm 1998. Ba con của chị đã trưởng thành và đều đi làm thợ xây cùng với bố tại địa phương .Chị Ân hiện đang chăn nuôi tại nhà. Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị là 4.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mua trâu và sửa sang chuồng trại phụcvụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. A., 48 years old, has participated in TYM Fund since 1998. She has three grown-up children, all of them work as construction workers with her husband in the home town. Mrs. A. raises livestock at home. Currently her family's income is VND4,000,000 per month.

In this loA. cycle, she wishes to borrow VND10,000,000 to buy buffaloes to raise and renovate the barn for livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy buffaloes to raise and renovate the barn for livestock.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị Cát  năm nay 55 tuổi,  gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Anh Hồng chồng chị là cán bộ hưu trí có thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng.  Năm 1998 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương để vay thêm vốn về đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi lợn và đây cũng là một trong những nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị bên cạnh  thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để mua lợn  và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi C. is 55 years old. She has three grown-up children. Mr Hong, her husband, is a pensioner with a pension of VND2,500,000 per month. In 1998, she joined TYM Fund to borrow money to invest in raising livestock. Currently, she raises pigs and this is one of the main sources of income for her family beside the husband's pension. In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND10,000,000 to buy pigs to raise and foods for them.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pigs to raise and foods for them.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hà năm nay 29 tuổi,  là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2008. Hiện tại chị đang buôn bán chiếu tại Hà Nội. Anh Hà chồng chị năm nay  28  tuổi cũng đang tham gia hỗ trợ vợ trong công việc buôn bán. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị với mức thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng . Với mức vốn 9.000.000đ dự định xin vay trong vòng vốn tới chị sẽ sử dụng để đầu tư cho công việc buôn bán chiếu của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. H. is 29 years old. She is a member of TYM Fund since 2008. Currently, she buys and sells sleeping mats in Hanoi. Mr. H., her husband, is 28 years old and helps her with the business. This business brings the major source of income for her family with a monthly income of VND4,000,000.

With a requested loan of VND9,000,000 in this loan cycle, she will invest more in the family's sleeping mats business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for selling sleeping mats

loans.name: Thi Hoe

texts.vi: Chị Trần Thị Hoè năm nay 27 tuổi,  gia đình chị có 1 con còn nhỏ.  Hiện nay chị đang cùng chồng chăn nuôi lợn gà tại nhà. Bên cạnh đó tranh thủ thời gian nông nhàn anh chị còn đi làm thuê nhằm tăng thu nhập và phát triển kinh tế gia đình.   Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm gà về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. Thi Hoe is 27 years old. Her family has one small child. Currently, Mrs. T. and her husband raise pigs and chickens for a living. In addition to that, they work for hire to increase their family's income. She would like to borrow 5,000,000 VND to invest in buying more chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị Ngân  năm nay 29tuổi,  chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2008 và đang kinh doanh hoa quả . Anh Quyết chồng chị làm xe ôm với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài thời gian đi làm anh cũng giúp đỡ chị rất nhiều vì thế công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị  phát triển tốt và cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm các loại hoa quả về bán.
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi N. is 29 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2008 and is currently selling vegetables. Her husband Quyet works as a motorbike cabbie with an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. In addition to his work, he also helps his wife with her vegetables business, which brings her an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND to invest in more vegetables to sell.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Dang Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Đặng Thị N. năm nay 27 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ đầu năm 2008. Hiện hai vợ chồng chị đều đang kinh doanh điện thoại, đồng hồ và kính mắt tại thị trấn Gia Lộc tỉnh Hải Dương. Bên cạnh kinh doanh các mặt hàng trên chồng chị còn làm thêm nghề sửa chữa điện thoại nên hàng tháng cho thu nhập rất ổn định( 4.000.000đ/ tháng)
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dang Thi N. is 27 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2008. She and her husband has a telephone, watch and eye glass business. In addition to selling those merchandises, her husband also fixes telephones so her family's income is at stable 4,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND to invest in her family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hoài năm nay 23 tuổi,  chị đang sống cùng chồng và một con nhỏ  tại thị trấn Gia Lộc tỉnh Hải Dương. Hiện taij chị đang làm hàng mã tại nhà còn anh Thứ chồng chị làm thợ nhôm kính.  Do thiếu vốn  đầu tư mua nguyên liệu phục vụ cho sản xuất hàng mã  nên năm 2008 chị Hoài đã tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương. Đến nay  qua 1 năm  được vay thêm vốn và sử dụng vốn hiệu quả  quả kinh tế gia đình chị đang ngày càng ổn định  hơn với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Với mức vốn 9.000.000đ dự định xin vay trong vòng vốn tới chị sẽ sử dụng để mua tre, giấy ....để phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất hàng mã của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. H. is 23 years old. She lives with her husband and small child at the town of Gia Loc, Hai Duong Province.
